Award.AwardTitle: Travel Awards for US based participants to attend the workshop "Model Theory 2013", June 10-15, 2013, Ravello, Italy
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal requests for travel funds to support US participants, particularly
graduate students and recent Ph.D.s, to attend the international
workshop Model Theory 2013 that will be held June 10-15 in Ravello Italy.


One of the objectives of this workshop will be
bringing together researchers in Model Theory and other areas of mathematics where
model theory has had significant applications. By presenting and discussion problems
as well as recent advances in these areas we hope to facilitate further interactions.

Another goal of the workshop is to provide an informal setting where graduate students and younger researchers from US
can learn about new trends and interact with one another as well as with prominent senior
mathematicians. There will be three tutorials on recent developments
in Model Theory given by experts and aimed mostly at young researchers.

The workshop is expecting participation from a large number of
graduate student and recent Ph.D.s.
Besides providing an opportunity for researchers to exchange ideas and discuss open problems, another
equally important goal of the workshop is to foster interaction among
graduate students and recent Ph.D by providing a setting
contacts with junior and senior researchers are naturally and easily made.

More information about the workshop can be found on its webpage
http://logica.dmi.unisa.it/Ravello/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided support for US national and US-based researchersto participate in the meeting ``Model Theory 2013" held in Ravello, Italy June 10-15, 2013. The meeting was one of the largest gatherings in model theory ever with 120 participants from all over the world. Speakers included most of the leading figures in modern model theory as well as key researchers from other areas of mathematics where model theory has had significant applications. The talks covered a wide range of current research in pure and applied model theory and closely related areas.  Multi-lecture tutorials aimed at graduate students and mid-career researchers were given on three important areas where model theory has had a major interaction with other areas of mathematics: i) the model theory of valued fiedls and the construction of Berkovich space; ii) model theory and geometric group theory;  iii) applications of o-minimality to diophantine geometry and number theory.  Postdoctoral researchers and graduate students had the opportunity to present their work in shorter lectures and poster sessions.

The award provided partial or full support for 18 US based researchers including 9 graduate students, 2 postdoctoral researchers and 2 early career researchers. 5 of the supported participants were invited speakers. 5 of the supported participants were women and 2 were underrepresented minorities.

Slides from all lectures and copies of posters from the poster session are available on the conference website.
